The game is actually fairly fun. It has lots of elements to be nostalgic about including old enemies updated and old obsticals. Stuff from the three former games amd I'm sire many other references to the more recent games I must have missed. It also has some new stuff that one only sees in this game. So over all a very decent game, one you should enjoy if you like the old sonic games or are new to sonic all together. It also has a newish feature, the homing attack  It's a 2d game which means the only ways to move are up, down, right or left. Something anyone who has played Pok√©mon, Mario, or other 2d games should be familiar with.   However my biggest complaint is the controls. I can't tell you how many times I died because the analog axis for the "looking up" or "ducking" action is too wide and the axis for moving to the right or left is too narrow, when standing still. It is very frustrating when you find usage of the homing attack a better way to move to the right than simply using the analog controls.   I was also a little disappointed to find that there isn't, or at least it appears that there isn't, a debug mode for android while a few sights cited a code for it on other formats (Nintendo 3ds, Ps4, ect.) The code was to ender the following combination at the title screen "left, left, left, right, right, right, up, down, up, down" or something to that effect. But on android there is no existing input for analog directions on the title screen as it uses touch screen controls.   However, you can use a controller with the game, I tried my ps4 controller which connects via Bluetooth. Unfortunately it has a tremendous lag between when you enter the command and the game responds to said command. I haven't yet tried entering the debug mod with the controller. This flaw, the delay in response, is not the game's fault though. I tried the controller on a few other games and got the same delay in response.   I would favor if they allowed for a D-pad type input option similar to what you would see with an Emulator or narrowed the analog axis for up and down and widened the left / roght axis when stationery innthe game. Besides easily avoidable deaths caused by this flaw, the game overall is very good amd worth a couple of bucks.

A couple of odd moments in level design and some occasionally odd looking graphics aside, it seems well put together with it's feet firmly in both the past and modern times.  But the controls. They work, because "Virtual direction pad/stick" is large and while initially a little tricky, is not beyond mastery. Here, the virtual joystick is TINY, making precise movement an exercise in pain. I was doing OK until I got to one level where the horribly imprecise controls made beating a moving hazard impossible. If you have especially tiny fingers you might be OK. But for someone my size it is just not practical to work with a virtual control stick that is probably 50% smaller than my thumb!
